WORK PERMITS
(Issue to blue identity card holders and others)


    2. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour how many work permits have been issued since May, 1968 (i) to blue identity card holders; and (ii) to others.

IN-SERVICE TRAINING
COURSES FOR TEACHERS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Education (a) how many teachers have attended in-service training courses, which will qualify them for incremental credits, up to the latest convenient date; (b) what is the basis of selection of teachers for participation in such courses; (c) how many teachers have attended more than one such course; (d) how many teachers who had undergone in-service training courses have been utilised in the Education Service; and (e) whether he will consider increasing the number of in-service training courses to enable more teachers to take advantage of such courses.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the first in-service course earning incremental credits was conducted in 1964, to date 1,873 teachers have attended in-service training courses which qualify them for incremental credits.

Column: 164



    Teachers who apply for participation in incremental benefit courses are selected by a duly constituted selection board on the basis of (a) aptitude; (b) qualifications; (c) relevance to the present teaching; and (d) recommendation from the principal of the school. Other things being equal, those who have not had the opportunity of attending any in-service courses are given more consideration. The only exception to this procedure is the course on the teaching of English as a second language. All teachers who are teaching this subject are required to attend this course in batches.

    As to the third part of the question, Sir, 17 teachers have attended more than one such course earning incremental credits.

    As to the fourth part of the question, Sir, teachers who had undergone in-service courses have been assigned to teaching subjects related to the training which they have received.

    As to the last part of the question, Sir, since the aim is to improve the quality of teachers, more in-service courses will be organised. However, with a view to economising on recurrent expenditure and, at the same time, to providing some kind of incentive, my Ministry has proposed to the Ministry of Finance a bonus scheme to replace the present incremental credit scheme. Several non-incremental benefit in-service courses have been conducted for teachers in various subjects. Every teacher who takes pride in his teaching and wants to bring up to date his knowledge of the content and technique will, of his own interest, volunteer to enrol in such courses. The desire to achieve fulfilment in their chosen profession should be the best and ultimate motivation.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, my supplementary question is also in parts.

    First, can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education explain why 17 teachers have taken more than one such in-service course?

Column: 165



    Second, the Parliamentary Secretary mentioned that, as far as possible, those who took additional courses teach the subjects in which they have been trained. Can he categorically state that these teachers teach the subjects in which they have been trained?

    Third, in what form is the bonus scheme going to replace the incremental credit scheme?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, the reason why 17 teachers have done more than one such course is that they find that they are subject teachers for more than one subject and it is in their own interest to up-grade themselves.

    There are cases of drop-out of teachers who have undertaken in-service courses and who are not utilised for teaching the subjects in which they have been trained. In such cases, their incremental credits have been withdrawn.

    As to the last part of the supplementary question regarding the bonus scheme which my Ministry has proposed, the details are being worked out and a final decision on the matter has not been made yet.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education say why it is at all necessary to offer bonus incentives to teachers to come forward for courses when large numbers of them have come forward for such courses without having such incentives?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are certain subjects which are not "hot favourites" with the teachers. As a result, certain incentives and bonuses have to be provided.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary saying that only subjects that are "hot favourites" attract teachers to attend these in-service courses?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, I would appreciate it if the Member for Telok Blangah could repeat his question.

Column: 166



    Mr Speaker: Mr Govindasamy, can you rephrase your question, please?

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary says that we have to offer incentives to attract teachers to attend the special courses in subjects that do not appeal to them. Does he mean that it is only the bonus which attracts the teachers to attend these courses?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: It appears to be so in certain subjects like English as a second language.

BRAIN DRAIN FROM
SINGAPORE


    4. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of any brain drain from the Republic as a result of persons going abroad for further education or specialised training and failing to return to Singapore on completion of their courses; and if he will consider taking steps to minimise this brain drain.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the problem of a brain drain from the Republic has not been seriously studied because it is not regarded as a serious one at present, particularly in regard to scientists and technologists going to other countries.

    Persons going abroad for further education or specialised training are either government scholars or private students. For government scholars in respect of whom proper records are maintained, the percentage who have failed to return to Singapore in the past on completion of a course is insignificant. For private students, no specific records are maintained. But the number who choose not to return has not been noticeable. This is perhaps because the number is small.

    Appropriate measures will be taken to minimise the brain drain from the Republic should the problem become serious.

PUBLIC TRANSPORT SYSTEM
(Committee to review)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications whether he will consider setting up a committee to review the public transport system in the Republic; to assess public needs in the next five years, and to make recommendations.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications (Mr Phua Bah Lee) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Punggol may recall that in July 1968, the Minister for Communications announced in Parliament that he would establish a Transport Advisory Board to study ways and means to improve the present public transport service in Singapore. This Board was, in fact, set up the following month and has since been holding regular monthly meetings.

    The Board submitted its first interim report to the Minister in February this year and Government's acceptance of most of the Board's recommendations was announced in his speech at the opening ceremony of the Transport and Communications Exposition on 1st August. The most important recommendation, being the compulsory wearing of crash helmets by motor cyclists, scooterists and their pillion-riders, is being implemented in stages as from November 1969.

    The Board is currently studying the problem of uniform legislation for bus companies in Singapore and also the possible re-routing of existing bus routes so as to provide more efficient and direct services for commuters from their homes to their places of work.

    As for long-term solutions of our transport problems, this needs the attention of better qualified professional experts and planners. Two senior officials from the London Transport Board have already submitted "a preliminary study of possible new measures to improve and expand Singapore's mass transport facilities", which report is being examined by officials from my Ministry and those from the Ministries of National

Column: 168

Development and Finance. Furthermore, a team of United Nations advisers attached to our State and City Planning Office have in the past two years been studying and assessing Singapore's long-term needs in public transport, including the long-range aspects of providing a mass transit system for Singapore.

    In view of the existence of the Transport Advisory Board to find short-term solutions to our transport problems and the assistance of U.N. experts now attached to the State and City Planning Office to examine our long-term needs in public transport and to recommend ways and means to meet them, I do not think there is a need to set up yet another committee for the purpose, as indicated by the Member for Punggol.

PAYA LEBAR INTERNATIONAL
AIRPORT
(Adequacy of facilities)


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications (a) whether the present facilities at the Paya Lebar International Airport are sufficient to cope with the anticipated increase in air traffic in the 1970s; and (b) whether there are any plans to meet the anticipated increase in passenger traffic with the introduction of the Jumbo Jets.

    Mr Phua Bah Lee (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the present facilities at our Paya Lebar International Airport were planned to meet the requirements of present generation jet aircraft such as the Boeing 707, Douglas DC 8 and VC 10. To cope with the newer and larger types of aircraft such as the Boeing 747 jumbo jets and supersonic aircraft like the TU 144 or Concorde which are expected to be in commercial service in the late 1970s, a firm of aviation consultants in the United Kingdom was appointed to prepare a master plan for the development of our Airport for the next two decades, i.e., up to the period 1990. This firm of consultants, Scott, Wilson, Kirkpatrick & Partners, commenced work in March 1968 and its report was

Column: 169

submitted to Government in May this year.

    The consultants' recommendations have been studied and, so far, only the first phase of development for immediate improvements to existing facilities, e.g., alterations and extensions to the present terminal building, improvement to taxiways and extension of the jet apron, to cater for traffic up till 1976, has been approved and is estimated to cost over $7 million. This does not, however, include projects which have just been completed, namely, the extension and strengthening of the runway from 9,000 feet to 11,000 feet and the commissioning of the Instrument Landing System amounting to over $5 million.

    As the medium- and long-term recommendations for further development of the Airport may involve capital expenditure to the order of over $600 million and advances in technology may result in certain proposals becoming obsolete, these proposals will have to be reviewed at the appropriate time by the Treasury, prior to implementation, if found necessary.

CITIZENS' CHILDREN BORN
OUTSIDE SINGAPORE
(Permanent residence in Singapore)


    7. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Defence if he will permit an infant born outside Singapore to enter and reside permanently in the Republic if either of his parents is a Singapore citizen and is permanently residing in Singapore.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, under category 5 of the Schedule to the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1966, any child under six years of age of a Singapore citizen may be considered for the issue of an entry permit to enter and reside permanently in the Republic. Applications for such entry permits are considered on the merits of each case.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister consider the case under file reference IMS/ENT/536/66?

Column: 170



    Mr Speaker: What was your question, Inche Aziz? I think the Minister might like you to repeat those figures?

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: The application was made by a father for the entry of his son, Haja Maideen. I have just given the file reference of his application. The application was made in 1966.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member will write and give me the relevant reference number, I will surely look into the case.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Can the Minister explain why a child under six years of age of a citizen cannot be given permanent residence in Singapore as of right, and why his application is a matter for "consideration" by the Immigration Department?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, first and foremost, the Immigration Department has to consider whether the child has a claim. He may be born in Singapore but we have first to look into his claim. Also, can the Member for Bras Basah guarantee that every child who claims to be born in Singapore and wants to reside here will be well looked after?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I think the Minister has not understood my question. I said that if a child is born outside Singapore of a resident citizen of Singapore, why cannot he be made a resident of Singapore as of right, and why must his application be subject to further consideration by the Immigration Department?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, if the Member had listened carefully, he would have heard my answer. My answer is: can the Member guarantee that every child who claims to be born in Singapore will be well looked after if he or she comes into Singapore?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, we must not forget that we are a socialist Government, and looking after the well-being of all our citizens is not the job of a Member of Parliament.

UPPER PAYA LEBAR ROAD
WIDENING PROJECT
(Compensation and resettlement of residents)


    8. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) how many residents along Upper Paya Lebar Road are affected by the widening of the road; (b) whether any compensation has been paid to those residents; and (c) what plans have been made to resettle them.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, my answer is:

    (a) A total of 301 squatters are affected by the Upper Paya Lebar Road widening project extending from Upper Serangoon Road to Airport Road;

    (b) Of this number, 129 cases have been settled so far and a total of $35,672 has been paid to those affected. Action is still being taken to deal with the remaining 172 cases;

    (c) The Housing and Development Board will provide alternative accommodation in its housing estates for those affected unless they elect to find their own accommodation.

AIRPORT ROAD
(Vehicular access to houses)


    9. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) how many residents along Airport Road have applied for permission to have entrances from the Road to their houses for vehicles; (b) how many of those applications have been (i) allowed; and (ii) rejected, and the reasons for the rejections; and (c) why have the authorities of Hong San School been refused permission to have an

Column: 172

entrance at Airport Road for the convenience of the pupils.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, my answer is:

    (a) A total of 12 applications have been received;

    (b) (i) Four applications were permitted separate entrances; (ii) of the other eight applications which requested four joint entrances, permission was refused because the entrances were either in the way of new bus bays or sited immediately next to existing bus bays. In all cases, the applicants have been provided with alternative access through the nearby car parks which were specially constructed by the Public Works Department for their use so as to prevent unauthorised parking of vehicles on the pedestrian paths and cycle tracks. Parking of motor vehicles along Airport Road is now prohibited;

    (c) Hong San School has already a vehicular access via an unmetalled road off Airport Road next to Lorong Tai Seng. The Airport Road has to be kept as free as possible for the smooth flow of traffic and it is considered undesirable to allow direct vehicular access from the school to Airport Road.

MODERN SANITATION
THROUGHOUT SINGAPORE


    10. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider extending the benefits of modern sanitation throughout the Republic.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the long-term objective of Government to provide modern sanitation throughout the island. However, the provision of modern sanitation is not only costly but requires careful planning. Therefore, the implementation of the objective has to be carried out in phases - priorities being given to development in some areas like urban renewal projects, Kallang Basin and Toa Payoh.

Column: 173



    Provision of adequate and modern sewage facilities for the population is an important element in our development plan. In 20 years the population of Singapore has nearly doubled to a total today of just over two million. The sewage system has been continuously expanded and just over half the population is now served by the system as compared to a quarter of the population in 1949.

HOUSING BOARD FLATS
AND SHOPHOUSES
(Allocation to residents of Bajerai Lane and Towner Road)


    11. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) if he will request the Housing and Development Board to allocate flats or shophouses, according to choice, to the residents of the Bajerai Lane and Towner Road areas who are affected by clearance action; and (b) if he will give an assurance that the Public Works Department and the Letting Section of the Housing and Development Board will co-ordinate their activities in the clearance of those areas so as to avoid any embarrassment or inconvenience to all parties concerned.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible to allocate particular flats or shophouses according to choice to residents affected by clearance action. But, in accordance with the present resettlement policy of the Housing and Development Board, offers for the selection of such clearance cases are always made of flats or shophouses that may be available for allocation from time to time.

    The Member can rest assured that clearance schemes are always carried out with the co-ordination of all the departments involved so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible. However, unforeseen difficulties may occur due to clearance in cases insisting on particular types of attractive accommodation and refusing to vacate the site

Column: 174

unless such alternative accommodation is offered to them. Often the type of accommodation desired may not be available or available in sufficient numbers to meet every request.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, are the flats at the Kallang Basin Estate reserved for people affected by development/clearance action of the Housing and Development Board?

    Mr Barker: Some of the flats in Kallang are reserved for people who have been evicted in the vicinity. They are given priority provided they desire to go to Kallang.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, why were vacant flats in the estate mentioned by me earlier not allocated to applicants who were affected by P.W.D. clearance action?

    Mr Barker: I am not aware of such cases, but if the Member will send me the particulars I will certainly look into them. But to cite particular cases in this House and ask me the reasons why allocations were not made puts me in a rather difficult position. I have not got the files here.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: I have the case file, but anyway we will deal with it later on. Will the Minister accept it that the people affected by P.W.D. clearance action should be treated in the same manner as those affected by Housing and Development Board clearance action as both the departments are under the same Ministry?

    Mr Barker: I would say yes.

INDUSTRIAL HEALTH UNIT
(Increase in staff and functional activities)


    12. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Health if he will consider (i) attaching a full-time medical officer to the Industrial Health Unit; and (ii) expanding the Unit and increasing its functional activities.

Column: 175



    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the question is in two parts, I shall answer it in two parts. The first part is concerned with the attaching of a full-time medical officer to the Industrial Health Unit. The Ministry of Health is aware of the limitations of the Ad Hoc Industrial Health Unit which was set up in October 1967 with a limited staff consisting of a part-time medical officer, an inspector of factories and a few office staff.

    Following the visit of an expert on occupational health from the International Labour Organisation in 1967-68, recommendations were put forward to expand the Ad Hoc Industrial Health Unit in terms of staff and activities. My Ministry recognises the need to establish a more effective Industrial Health Unit to promote industrial health which is incumbent upon our rapid industrial growth. A plan to expand the industrial Health Unit in terms of staff and activities is already in hand. In the provision for more staff, it is envisaged that a full-time medical officer and an industrial hygienist with an engineering background, in addition to eight other professional and non-professional staff, would be included.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I come now to the second part of the question which is regarding the expanding of the Unit and increasing its functional activities. Consequent upon the increase in the high-level staff of this Unit, it is our intention that the scope of the work of the Unit will be expanded to include the following:

    (i) to assess the occupational health problems in Singapore by selected examinations and evaluation of the working environment of our workers;

    (ii) to study and draw up preventive measures appropriate to local conditions;

    (iii) to formulate procedures for periodical medical examinations as a control on hazardous occupational groups;

Column: 176



    (iv) to undertake factory inspection of working environmental conditions and enforcement of relevant sections of the Factories Ordinance and related occupational legislation, normally administered by the Ministry of Labour, with reference to the health of the workers;

    (v) to advise and give information on occupational health to industries;

    (vi) to prepare codes of practice and modifications to present legislation and subsequent implementation;

    (vii) to undertake research and teaching in connection with the primary objectives of the occupational health programme in Singapore.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, if we assume that all the projects mentioned by the Minister just now are to be carried out, how many medical officers are required for these projects?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I presume the intention of the Member is that we should employ more medical officers to man the Industrial Health Unit. For a start, we are going to employ more staff, but we cannot all of a sudden employ as many medical staff as the Member would like us to. But in the light of experience that we have gathered from the amount of work involved, we shall certainly ask the Treasury to give us additional staff if and when required.

LIGHT DUES BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.06p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications (Mr Phua Bah Lee) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."
